content: The "Systemic Risk Designation Improvement Act of 2016" amends the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act by revising the table of contents and enhancing the supervision and regulation of certain nonbank financial companies and bank holding companies. The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act is amended to enhance supervision and regulation of certain nonbank financial companies and bank holding companies. The Dodd-Frank Act amends regulations for bank holding companies, allowing the Council to determine enhanced supervision and standards if financial distress or activities pose a threat to US financial stability. The Council uses Basel Committee's indicator-based approach to determine systemic importance of bank holding companies based on size, interconnectedness, substitutes availability, global activity, and complexity. GSIBs can be designated by law. The text discusses the designation of Global Systemically Important Banks by the Financial Stability Board and the corresponding regulatory changes to subsections of the law. The text discusses amendments to subsections of the law related to the designation of Global Systemically Important Banks by the Financial Stability Board. Amendments include changes to subsections (g), (h), and (i) by updating references and inserting new terms. The Dodd-Frank Act is amended to enhance supervision of bank holding companies previously determined under section 113. This includes changes to subsections (a)(1), (a)(2), and (b)(3) of the Act. The Dodd-Frank Act is amended to enhance supervision of bank holding companies with consolidated assets equal to or greater than $50,000,000,000, which have been the subject of a final determination under section 113. Amendments include removing the asset threshold and referring to companies subject to section 113 determinations. Section 11 of the Federal Reserve Act is amended to enhance supervision of bank holding companies with consolidated assets of $50,000,000,000 or more, which have been subject to a final determination under section 113 of the Dodd-Frank Act. This includes redesignating subsections and removing the asset threshold requirement. SEC. 5. The Financial Stability Oversight Council can initiate proceedings for a bank holding company under the Dodd-Frank Act upon enactment but cannot make a final determination before one year. Large bank holding companies with assets over $50,000,000,000 will be treated as if a final determination has been made during this period. SEC. 6 addresses the existing assessment termination schedule. Each bank holding company with total consolidated assets equal to or greater than $50,000,000,000, not previously determined under Dodd-Frank Act, will be subject to assessments like those that have been determined. The total amount collected from all assessed companies will be limited to $115,000,000, with expedited assessments if needed to reach this target. The Secretary of the Treasury will offer payment period options for bank holding companies to pay assessments before fiscal year 2018. $60,000,000 will go to the Financial Stability Oversight Council for administrative costs, and $55,000,000 will go to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for resolution costs. The Insurance Corporation will cover resolution costs resulting from the Act and its amendments. Bank holding companies assessed under this section will no longer be subject to assessments if they receive a final determination under the Dodd-Frank Act. Payments made by these companies will not be refunded. Additionally, bank holding companies subject to a final determination under the Dodd-Frank Act will not be assessed under subsection (a) solely by operation of the Act.
